title: mh370 air traffic controllers mystery never solved
story: The packed passenger jet dropped off the radar screens of flight monitors in Malaysia just five seconds after it crossed into Vietnamese airspace.But the controller monitoring its progress in Kuala Lumpur was dealing with other traffic on his screen and didn’t notice it had vanished.Its been reported by the Atlantic that when he finally did, he assumed that it was now in the hands of his counterparts in Ho Chi Minh.However, Vietnamese controllers saw the Boeing  - which vanished with  on board - cross into their airspace and then also disappear.They then apparently misunderstood rules which meant they were supposed to inform Malaysia immediatelya plane did not show up.They tried repeatedly to contact the flight crww of the aircraft - which is believed to have crashed into the ocean - but to no avail.By the time they finally picked up the phone to inform Kuala Lumpur,  minutes had passed since its sudden disappearance.What ensued was an exercise in confusion and incompetence full of blunders, say those close to the long-running investigationKuala Lumpur’s Aeronautical Rescue Coordination Centre should have been notied within an hour of the disappearance, they say.Malaysia Airlines Flight MH took off from Kuala Lumpur and was heading to Beijing with  people on board.Passengers included Chinese calligraphers, a couple on their way home to their young sons after a long-delayed honeymoon and a construction worker who hadnt been home in a year.But at .am on March , , Malaysia Airlines lost contact with MH close to Phuket island in the Strait of Malacca.Before that, Malaysian authorities believe the last words heard from the plane, from either the pilot or co-pilot, was Good night Malaysian three seven zero.Satellite pings from the aircraft suggest it continued flying for around seven hours when the fuel would have run out.Experts have calculated the most likely crash site around , miles west of Perth, Australia.But a huge search of the seabed failed to find any wreckage - and there are a number of alternative theories as to its fate.However, it eventually took more than four hours to alert rescuers - which means it is virtually impossible to pinpoint where and when it went down.Five pieces, thought to be from the Malaysia Airlines plane, later washed up in Madagascar - more than , miles from Vietnam.Aviation expert Victor Iannello believes one fragment, which appears to be from the interior floorboard, is consistent with a “high-speed impact.More than  bits of aircraft debris have so far been collected from ious places around the world over the past five years.However, only three wing fragments that washed up along the Indian Ocean have been confirmed to be from the missing flight.Its been reported earlier this year that the pilot was in control until the very end but made abnormal turns before crashing.French investigators have been given access to a considerable amount of flight data sent during the flight prior to the crash.Official documents lend weight to fears pilot Zaharie Ahmad Shah, , crashed into the sea in a murder-suicide, they were cited as saying.Some feared Russian president Vladimir Putin was involved in the hijacking of MH.US Science writer Jeff Wise claimed Putin spoofed the planes navigation data so it could fly unnoticed into Baikonur Cosmodrome so he could hurt the West.French ex-airline director Marc Dugain accused the US military of shooting down the plane because they feared it had been hijacked.Malaysia police chief Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar suggested the disappearance could have been the result of a suicide.He claimed someone on board could have taken out a large le insurance package before getting on the plane, so they could treat their family or pay back the money they owed.Historian and writer Norman Davies suggested MH could have been remotely hacked and flown to a secret location as a result of sensitive material being carried aboard the jet.Malaysia Airlines found a -inch crack in the fuselage of one of its planes, days before MH disappeared.The Federal Aviation Administration insists it issued a final warning two days before the disappearance.But the Daily Mirror claimed the missing jet did not have the same antenna as the rest of the Boeing s so it did not receive the warning.Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull unexpectedly said it was “very likely that the captain planned this shocking event”.He claimed the pilot wanted to create the worlds greatest mystery.Another theory claimed that he hijacked his own plane in protest of the jailing of then-Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, and as a way to destabilise the corrupt government of Najib Razak.Another seemingly far-fetched idea said the pilot had deliberately crashed the plane to cover his track as he had parachuted out of the plane so he could spend the rest of his le with his girlfriend who was waiting in a boat in the sea.In the wake of the incident, South Korea noted that North Korea nearly took out a Chinese plane which had  passengers on board, on March , .Some fear Pyongyang shot the plane down, but others believe it was hijacked and erted into the communist nation.One theory claims that because many relatives were able to hear a ringing tone for up to four days after the crash so the doomed jet could not have smashed into the Indian Ocean.Nineteen families have all claimed the devices of their loved ones rang for up to four days after the jet went missing.However, wireless analysts claim that phone firms sometimes use a phantom ringing sound when the device is not active, the Daily Star reports.In September , British video producer Ian Wilson claimed to have found the missing aircraft using Google Maps.Despite millions being spent on the search to located the wreckage, the Brit sleuth believes he has found the jet in a mountainous area of the Cambodian jungle.In response, the Chinese government used observation company Space View to focus in on the high-altitude area on the outskirts of Phnom Penh.However, the firm claim there was no sign of any plane, least of all the Malaysian Airlines aircraft which has been missing since March .An MH sleuth has claimed that locals in Cambodia told him they saw a plane believed to be the doomed Malaysia Airlines flight crashing in the jungle.If the jet was flying north then possible locations could stretch as fast as the border between Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan to Thailand.The Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak originally asked the Kazakhstan leader Nursultan Nazarbayev to set up a search operation in the country but this quickly got sidelined as the rescue efforts focused on the Indian Ocean.The doomed flight is said to have mysteriously “flew round in circles” and veered of course shortly before disappearing.Data from British satellites could indicate the plane was oddly circling above the Pacic Ocean in South East Asia in the moments before it vanished.Aviation expert Jeff Wise, author of the Plane That Wasnt There, said data from Inmarsat, may suggest MH was flying bizarrely during its last minutes.Usually a jet will circle at a fixed altitude after being instructed to do so by air traffic control before being allowed to land at an airport.A satellite called F had made contact with the plane in the hours after it went missing via a series of what is technically known as electronic “handshakes”.Mr Wise explained: Just as the motion of a speeding train makes the tone of its whistle go up or down, the relative motion of the satellite and the aeroplane shts the frequency of the radio signals transmitted between them.MH’s disappearance has also given rise to a slew of conspiracy theories - some far more bizarre than others.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lonely pensioner tears christmas tree carol
story: Terrence, , was brought some festive joy at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, by students from Oldham College and BBC Breakfast host Dan Walker.They paid him a Christmas visit after hed said earlier on the show that he struggled with loneliness and didnt have a Christmas tree in his house.Mr Walker surprised Terrence on his doorstep and introduced him to four students from the nearby college — one of whom had brought a Christmas tree.Terrence came to say hello but he started crying as he greeted the well-wishers inidually.After the students finished decorating the tree, Mr Walker took Terrence to his front door where the college choir sang Silent Night, which overwhelmed him.Terrence told BBC Breakfast: What used to happen, I used to go round to my mothers on Christmas Day because I always cooked a meal for her here.I always took the thing round to her, and I used to buy her little bits all the time, like cigarettes and all this sort of stuff, and I used to parcel them all up at Christmas and put them in a pillow case and take them round to her.One day, Ill never forger her saying to me, she said, Do you know, without you, bringing me my presents at Christmas, I wouldnt have any presents would I I often think about that now. story: Andrea Martinez found her dachshund puppy Ziggy vomiting on Saturday night and rushed him to an animal hospital in Utah.During Ziggys surgery, it became apparent the puppy would need a more complicated and expensive procedure.A hospital staffer erroneously dialled the owner of a dferent dog, also named Ziggy, it is claimed.They explained the situation and asked whether she would like to proceed with the surgery, or put the pooch down.The other owner opted to have the pet euthanized, not knowing that the dog in question was not hers, it is alleged.At .am on Monday, Martinez said she got a call telling her Ziggy had died.She wrote on Facebook: They let a stranger decide my dogs fate.They robbed me the choice of saying at-least We tried.I feel so sick and cant stop crying. Martinez said Ziggy followed her everywhere, cuddled with her every night and helped with her anxiety, and he was also her young daughters best friend.She said: How do you tell a six-year-old her best friend died and we didnt have a choice to try everything to stop him from dying.This whole thing seriously makes me so sick to my stomach.Martinez said the vet has apologised and waived Ziggys hospital bill.The vet also provided an urn for his ashes and a Christmas tree ornament featuring the puppys paw print, it is claimed.On Tuesday, Martinez posted a message on her Facebook page saying she has decided not to pursue legal action against the animal hospital.She said: It was a honest mistake, they owned it, and are taking steps to make things okay.Ziggy was really sick and from the sounds of it, I’m not sure he would’ve even made it after all said and done.I do wish we would’ve had to chance to find out tho but le happens and we have to learn to adjust and learn and grow from it.I will forever miss him but at least I know he’s not in pain anymore.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The frisky  calendar — showing a the working men of Worcestershire in their birthday suits — has completely sold out raising almost £, for the Motor Neurone Disease Association.Neil Grubb, , a painter from Redditch, Worcs., had the idea a couple of years ago-and it came from skinny-dipping with his friend Andy Lent in July .The two mates snapped a funny bum picture, to cheer up Andy’s we Lisa, who was suffering from Motor Neurone Disease.Sadly Lisa passed away a year ago but Neil was determined to make the funny calendar in her memory — and so he did with Andy and Lisas consent.MND is a fatal, rapidly progressing disease that affects the brain and spinal cord and has no cure.Neil, a dad -of two- said: In July last year I went skinny dipping with Andy and we got someone to take a picture of us just to prove to our wives that we had done it.When they saw the photo, they were in hysterics, just to see Lisa’s face light up, was worth it.Somebody said for a laugh ‘you ought to do a calendar’ and I didn’t think about it again.Around the time Lisa was bad, I thought about it and checked with hershe would be ok with it and she was.There have been a few friends and acquaintances willing to help so I started working on it and have sold about  of them so far.They are everyday blokes and when I said what I wanted to do, most of them were happy to help.One or two said they were a bit shy at first — during a photo shoot they were carrying plastic plant pots in front of them and one bloke had a shot of vodka to get courage but we all had a laugh and did it in the end.“We are just doing in memory of Lisa, she was a lovely woman, and we’d like to help others and raise awareness for motor neuron disease. “For more information visit the MND Association.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: exit polls 2019 uk general election
story: And with politics more volatile than ever, the exit poll is being very closely watched by voters and party insiders up and down the country.Like prior general elections, just after pm, the main broadcasters announced the findings of this year’s exit poll.Find out what time the winner will be announced here.According to the exit poll, Boris Johnson is on course to claim a signicant majority with Labour floundering on .An exit poll is a survey of a small proportion of voters across the UK.The exit poll will estimate how many seats will be won by each party.The exit poll is based on  constituencies in England, Scotland and Wales.The constituencies are chosen to be demographically representative of the country.They are balanced between urban and rural seats.They are also weighted slightly in favour of marginal seats.The same constituencies are surveyed from one election to the next so its consistent.Exit pollsters are based at a selective poling station in a chosen constituency.Some voters emerging from the polling stations are asked - every th voter, for example - by people employed by polling specialists Ipsos Mori to fill in a replica ballot paper without anyone watching.They then put the replica ballot paper into a box and its opened later.The exit poll is primarily used to calculate turnout and electoral swing - the extent of change in voter support compared to the previous election.The results are then analysed by a team of experts at a location in London.Data cant be released before the polls have closed.Due to only a small sample of voters filling out the replica ballot papers, those doing so are likely to be younger, so this may skewer results.Also, voters head to the polls at dferent times so a single exit poll may not give a true reflection of the overall outlook of the national vote.However, pollsters tend toto the same polling stations at the same times at each election.And by comparing these results it is possible to work out how voting has changed in that particular constituency.A famous example of an election poll error happened in .Two exit polls predicted a hung parliament - but the actual vote revealed the Tory government under John Major held their position.Investigations later revealed a number of causes that led to the miscalculation - including the shy Tory factor and inadequate demographic data.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain one national freedom other brexit paralysis
story: One path leads to British independence under Conservative leader Boris Johnson - but the other path follows a far darker course into chaos under Jeremy Corbyn’s Marxist cult.A Johnson victory should usher in a new age of prosperity and national freedom, while a Corbyn triumph will end in Brexit paralysis and financial bankruptcy.A Tory Government will ensure that Britain remains an advanced western economy, where taxes are kept down and enterprise encouraged, where as a Labour Government will turn our country into a basket case, wrecked by trade union bullying and the confiscation of wealth.Every citizen who genuinely cares about our future and cherishes British values therefore has a duty to vote against Corbyn’s hard-left Labour.In practice, that requires everyone - from Tory Remainers to hard Brexiteers - backing the Tories - because only a vote for Boris Johnson can be guaranteed to prevent a brutal Corbyn regime.A vote for the Liberal Democrats or the Brexit Party is not a wasted vote in this election -its something far more dangerous.It is effectively an act of support for Corbyn, forthere is another hung Parliament he will almost certainly emerge as the new Prime Minister.The same is true of moderate, centrist Labour voters who kid themselves that they can back their local Labour candidate while still hoping to avoid the calamity of a Corbyn Government.This is just irresponsible self-deceit. Every vote for Labour brings the Corbyn revolution a step closer.That catastrophe could easily happen this week.In recent opinion polls, the Tories have maintained a consistent lead over Labour by about  per cent - enough for a comfortable majority.But in some surveys, the gap has fallen to just  points, while one poll at the weekend suggested a Conservative majority of just .Moreover, as the last two General Elections proved, the polls can be badly wrong. The result this time could go down to the wire.What the country needs to ensure Corbyn’s defeat is a vast coalition of voters united by the one aim of keeping him out of Downing Street.This was meant to be the Brexit election but it has rightly turned into a referendum on Corbyn’s spectacular unfitness for high office.And the only result should be a wholesale rejection of his bid for power.To achieve that, all anti-Corbyn voters – no matter what their past allegiances or their personal hostility to Johnson – must vote tactically for the Conservatives.Jeremy Corbyn and his shadow Chancellor John McDonnell must be stoppedThroughout the campaign, Remain supporters have talked feverishly of the potential for anti-Tory tactical voting to stop Brexit.But far more potent would be a wave of pro-Tory tactical voting to keep out Corbyn.At the heart of such a drive must lie the millions of decent, patriotic voters in Labour’s heartlands of the North and the Midlands, who have backed the party all their lives but are now profoundly disillusioned with Corbyn.If they held their noses and supported Johnson, then Labour would face annihilation.There are already signs that this could be happening.The so-called “Red Wall” of around  Labour marginals from Yorkshire to Wales, characterised by seats like Bolsover in Derbyshire and Crewe in Cheshire, appears to be crumbling.If a new army of Red Tory voters materialises on Thursday, the damage to Corbyn could be phenomenal.This week were reports that Labour are even in trouble in Leigh, where Joanne Platt has a majority of almost , and which is only th on the Tories’ target list.Similarly, the latest poll in the Lincolnshire port of Grimsby, which has been held by Labour for generations, shows a big lead for the Tories.This mood of revolt against political loyalties was captured in the words of one café worker in Labour-held Wrexham, North Wales, who said at the weekend: “I’ve always voted Labour and my family always voted Labour. On Thursday I shall be voting Tory.”People like her recognise that traditional Labour – the party of Clem Attlee, John Smith and Tony Blair – is now dead, replaced by a dogmatic, intolerant movement dedicated to the overthrow of capitalism.The election campaign has only reinforced Labour’s unfitness for office.Lavish pledges of free services and extravagant spending increases have been dished out like confetti, shattering the last remnants of the party’s economic credibility.Meanwhile, Labour has nothing coherent to say about Brexit beyond the threat of yet more dither and delay.It is no wonder that the five million Labour voters who backed Leave in the  referendum are in such despair.Boris himself put it well on a visit to Grimsby yesterday when he said that Labour’s Brexit stance represented “the great betrayal, orchestrated from Islington by politicians who sneer at your values and ignore your votes.”But it is not just Leave voters who should back the Tories. Remainers who loathe the idea of a Corbyn regime should do so as well.A hard-left Government is too big a price for stopping Brexit, for which the British people democratically voted three years ago.The arch pro-EU Tory rebel Dominic Grieve, now standing as an independent in his Beaconsfield constituency, said recently that he was “absolutely satisfied that Mr Corbyn would be a disaster in Downing Street.”Yet Grieve is making that dire possibility more likely by trying to siphon off votes from the Tory party.Indeed, all the opposition parties are acting as Corbyn’s allies, whatever their protestations.Nigel Farage’s Brexit party, in particular, could still badly split the anti-Corbyn vote in a string of Northern and Midlands seats, like Hartlepool.The latest poll in the constituency shows the Brexit Party on  per cent and the Tories on  per cent, a far higher combined total of Labour’s  per cent.In Doncaster North, held by Ed Miliband, Labour is on  per cent against a combined total of  per cent for the Brexit Party and the Conservatives.Further south, a vote for Jo Swinson’s Liberal Democrats is realistically a vote for Corbyn, just as in Scotland, support for the SNP will help to propel Corbyn into Downing Street.The choice is stark. Our country’s security, liberty and growth can only be secured by theof a Conservative Government.There is nothing to fear from the continuation in office of Boris Johnson, who stands in the long tradition of one-nation Conservatism epitomised by Benjamin Disraeli and Winston Churchill.But there is everything to fear from Corbyn’s ascent to power.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how are general election votes counted
story: Millions of votes have been cast, but how are they all counted  Heres everything you need to know.There are two stages to counting votes at UK general elections.At the first stage, count staff will be comparing the actual numbers of ballot papers in each ballot box against the ballot paper account.This is a form completed by the Presiding Officer at each polling station accounting for the ballot papers they have issued.Ballot boxes are opened and emptied onto tables. The empty boxes are shown to everyone present.This stage is crucial as it checks that all ballot papers are properly accounted for and that the number of ballot papersIn stage , ballot papers from dferent ballot boxes are mixed to preserve the secrecy of the vote.The papers are then allocated to count teams which will sort ballot papers by candidate.As long as the intention of the voter is clearly apparent, the vote can be accepted as valid and be counted.After the sorting is complete, count teams will count the number of votes cast for each candidate.Once all of the valid votes and any rejected votes have been added together and checked against the total number of ballot papers from the first stage of the count, the acting ing officerwill share the result with candidates and their agents before the official announcement.At a UK Parliamentary election, the ARO must take reasonable steps to begin stage  of the count by am.A number of factors might impact on when the votes can begin to be counted, for example the geography of the constituency and how long it takes to get the ballot boxes in from the polling stations.This stage is crucial as it checks that all ballot papers are properly accounted for and that the number of ballot papers delivered to the count matches the number expected.Times can y but the public will wake up knowing who has won the election, with all counts expected to be completed around am.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The star, who played the prime minister in Christmas classic Love Actually, has pledged support for candidate Luciana Berger, who is standing in the marginal seat of Londonaposs Finchley and Golders Green. In the run up to the election, Grant has been vocal about tactical voting in an attempt to unseat the Tories by choosing who to vote for based on who is most likely to win against the current leading party. Deborah Meaden  The business guru and Dragonsapos Den star said she was giving her full support to the Lib Dems. Meaden took to Twitter saying: Another reason I am voting @LibDems. According to the Institute of Fiscal studies theirs is the most sensible costed Budget...and I agree. Glad they are supporting a referendum, revoke was making me very uncomfortable..they now have my full on support. Chris Martin  Coldplay frontman Chris Martin spoke out earlier this week about his plans to vote for the Lib Dems. Speaking to the Sunday Times, Martin initially jokes he would be voting for the Monster Raving Loony Party, before saying he would probably vote Liberal Democrat”. Martin’s affinity for the Lib Dems was hinted at during the  election, when he attended a Nick Clegg event held in the Commons alongside Razorlight’s Johnny Borrell. Dom Joly The comedian and sketch artist regularly tweets his support for the Liberal Democrats, encouraging voters to elect Cheltenham candidate Max Wilkinson. Conservatives Alan Sugar  While Alan Sugar cannot cast a vote in the election due to sitting in the House of Lords, but earlier this month said he would Back Borishe were allowed to vote. title: general elections always held thursday
story: NewsGeneral Elections are always held on a Thursday for a very, very British reasonPeople up and down the country will be heading to the polling station today to cast their vote in the  General Election - but why does it always happen on a Thursday ShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  DEC NewsPeople will head to the polling stations today "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Today is your chance to have your say on how our country is run for the next few years, with Boris Johnson , Jeremy Corbyn , Jo Swinson and the other party leaders all hoping for your vote at the polling station. Thereaposs a slight feeling of Groundhog Day about the whole thing - with this being our third election in just four years as well as the Brexit referendum.While the policies and faces have been dferent each times weaposve drawn our X in the box, there is one thing all of the votes have had in common - theyaposve all been held on a Thursday. But why  Unsurprisingly, itaposs not just a massive coincidence and there is a very British reason why weaposre always asked to head out and vote on the fourth day of the week.  Votes are held on dferent days in dferent countries, and there are many theories behind Britainaposs Thursday tradition. One states that Friday was traditionally payday, meaning workers would be more likely to go to the pub than rouse themselves to vote. There were also concerns thatit was held on Sunday, a priest might try to influence the publicaposs votes through their sermons. Thursday, on the other hand, was market day and large numbers of people would be travelling into town anyway, so it therefore made sense to set it up then.  And itaposs been that way ever since. Before the th century most elections took place over weeks rather than in a single day, which meant people could cast their vote whenever was convenient for them.The last general election not on held a Thursday was on October ,  — which was a Tuesday.

The polls have Boris Johnsonaposs Conservatives tipped to win either an overall House of Commons majority or the most seats in a hung parliament.Of course, anything is possible, andJeremy Corbynaposs Labour Party does win an overall majority it would have a radically dferent impact on Britainaposs future.So how will these radically dferent forks in the road impact the state of the UK  Our head of politics Jason Beattie has outlined the dferent options facing the UK. Boris Johnson wins an overall majority Brexit: The Prime Minister plans to railroad his withdrawal agreement through Parliament before Christmas to make sure we leave the EU by January . Far from getting Brexit done this triggers the start of months,not years, of trade talks with the EU and other countries, including the US, India and Australia.Johnson has pledged to get a trade deal with the EU by December . If he fails we could face a no-deal Brexit on that date. What happens next will depend on the size of the Tory majority. If Johnson wins comfortably he should be able to play for time butit is a narrow margin then he will be in hock to the hard Brexiteers in his party. Public services: The Tories have promised more nurses, extra money for schools and hospitals and , more police officers.But their spending plans only envisage more money for the NHS, with education, councils and the Home Office spending still below pre- levels. And they depend on what happens with Brexit. If there is no trade deal the economy could slide and the Tories will not have money to invest in public services. This could lead to a stinging backlash from voters.  The UK: The Conservatives’ Brexit plans could lead to the break up of the United Kingdom.Leaked Treasury documents showed that Northern Ireland will be “symbolically” cut off from the rest of the UK because it will remain under EU for trade and there will be checks on imports between the mainland and Ulster. Public services: Labour will want to press ahead with its plans to raise taxes on business and the richest %.Rail, water and the Royal Mail could be brought back into public ownership. There would be a big investment in social care, the NHS and education. The SNP is likely to support much of this but the Lib Dems are opposed to many of Labour’s policies. Could scrapping Trident be the price Labour pays for the SNP support   The UK: If Corbyn can form a Government with SNP support then a second Scottish referendum is highly likely.Labour has indicated this would be an issue for later in the parliamentary term. A new Brexit deal is unlikely to isolate Northern Ireland as Corbyn is looking for an agreement that keeps the whole of the UK in a customs union. The leaders: What happens to the leaders will depend on the result and who can form a government. If the numbers fall in Labour’s favour and Corbyn becomes PM then Boris Johnson may try to cling on as leader.But he will be under pressure to quit having thrown away the Tory lead in the polls and the chance for a fourth term in government. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI was a guest on the Jeremy Vine radio show. I was asked to talk about my experience as an AE doctor as part of an election special alongside GP Siobhan Brennan. We were given a few minutes to introduce what we perceive to be the problems in the NHS that politicians should be addressing before responding to Conservative Health Secretary Matt Hancock and Shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth in a planned debate. However, this did not happen. At the last minute we were asked to leave the studio. We were told Matt Hancock would only consent to an interviewwe first left the room. All of this happened during a live broadcast in which Hancock went on to disingenuously praise the efforts of NHS staff to the listening public whilst in reality being too scared to even speak to us. Iaposve never spoken on a live media show before as frankly Iaposm terried. I’m not a aposmedia-savvyapos person. When asked to do this interview I immediately refused but when no-one  came forwardI realised thatever there was a time to say what I felt, it was now. I have always had strong views about the political context in which I do my job, and have always felt thankful that I donapost have to work in a toxic private system like the United States. Despite its rusty edges and leaky ceilings, the NHS has always been accessible to the community I live in and people’s ability to pay hasnapost affected whether or not I can help them. Since the  Health and Social care Act was introduced this has slowly become a distant memory. I believe most of what we think of as the fundamental principles of the NHS have now been eroded - I now have to consider whether a patient will be able to pay for their care before treating them. The government have established a cruel infrastructure for charging people who they deem ineligible for free healthcare, and it’s us as NHS staff that have to enforce it. Drugs are routinely unavailable because big pharmaceutical companies have monopolies on making and selling them. This means that we can’t access medication we need to treat common conditions in emergency scenarios and patient care becomes less safe. And now Iaposm facing an election whereelected to government it seems likely the Conservatives will open the NHS market to US trade deals, meaning our healthcare system, originally set up to provide aposfree at the point of access care to all who need itapos, will be run with multinational corporations making a profit from the work I do every day - treating vulnerable people on one of the worst days in their lives. I wish I’d been given the opportunity to speak to Matt Hancock. I would have told him how privatisation of our NHS so badly affects the job I do. Thereaposs a mis-held belief thatdoctors and nurses’ salaries are still being paid by the government and aposmost peopleapos still get free healthcare, then the NHS has not yet been privatised. But privatisation is everywhere. Many staff I work with are now employed not by the NHS on decent terms and conditions, but by subsidiary companies who have taken over contracts to provide estates, portering, security and catering. Privatisation is in the car parksthe drugs we use, the operations that we pay private hospitals to aposhostapos to reduce waiting lists and the card machines used to charge migrants who probably canapost pay anyway. Keep Our NHS Public have shown us over the last decade how privatisation has been a slow burning affair, purposefully kept away from the public becausethey really understood the full implications, there would be riots. In the debate on Jeremy Vine before us Andre Jones implied that we shouldn’t ‘be bothered’ about who cleans the toilets or does the deliveries. This is a total disregard for the importance of cleanliness and other support services in hospitals.  Just as I am likely to do my job better with better training and fairer terms and conditions that enable me to work well, so are the cleaning staff who are integral to the day to day ing of the hospital. Thanks to the other guest Owen Jones who reminded us that we will be a weaker partner in a trade deal with the US and will likely be forced to open the NHS to US multinationals. And all these things are privatised in the name of aposcost savingapos whilst the politicians deny its even happening and Johnson gets to spout his insincere line about the NHS being a aposnational treasureapos. Matt Hancock talked a lot about increasing staff numbers as part of the solution. This is something the Conservatives have been talking about for a long time, and they havenapost improved things at all. Staff morale is at the centre of chronically low staff shortages and current doctors are looking to take early retirement because the job is too much. There are currently , vacancies in the NHS. This includes , vacant nursing posts. Simultaneously in the last  years, we have tragically lost  nurses as a result of suicide. Unhappy staff cannot treat vulnerable patients well. story: NewsLaws that keep your vote secret in a general election - and where you paper goesAs we all prepare for the general election on December , many are being very vocal about their support - but for those wanting to keep their choice to themselves, how secret is your vote ShareCommentsByMatthew PorterLuke MatthewsAudience Writer:,  DEC NewsThere are laws in place to ensure it remains a secret "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. On Thursday weaposll be heading to the polling booths to cast our vote in the  general election .Social media has been boiling over with those giving their views and trying to persuade us to vote for one party or the other, from both politicians and the public. As many very publicly voice their support, others prefer to keep their vote to themselves - and there are strict laws in place to ensure votes can remain private. It means nobody should be able to find out who you voted for, unless you decide to tell them. In theory, someone with access to both the ballot papers and registration numbers for any given constituency could trace inidual votes - but is this possible   Under the Representation of the People Act , ballot papers and marked copies of the electoral register have to be safely deposited with the Government. To ensure any allegations of corrupt or illegal practices which may come to light after an election can be properly investigated, our papers are sealed and kept in storage for one year. Once this time elapses and all is well, our voting cards are sent to be incinerated and destroyed, meaning there will be no lasting record of how you voted.

title: queen kate middleton royals dont
story: NewsWhy Queen, Kate Middleton and other royals dont vote - even though theyre allowed toThe Queen, Kate Middleton, Princes Charles, William and Harry wont be heading to the polling station to vote in the  General ElectionShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  DEC NewsSorry guys! "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email As we all prepare to cast our votes in the  General Election , there are a group of people who wonapost be heading out to the polling station - the Royal Family.While many believe the Queen and her relatives arenapost allowed to put an X on the ballot paper this isnapost actually the case.The truth is, the Queen can vote. She is eligible and perfectly within her rights to go out and have her say.But you probably wonapost spot her down the local polling station, and the same goes for Prince Charles, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and other members of The Firm. The monarch is entitled in law to cast a ballot in general elections, but royal tradition sees her choose to abstain. By convention the Queen doesnapost vote, rather than because of a legal impediment, says an Electoral Commission spokesman. Historian and author Sarah Gristwood says itaposs consistently been a policy of this Queen, since her early days as head of state, to stay completely above the fray. It follows on from a major reinvention of the monarchy following the end of World War One and the establishment of the House of Windsor. Even though she doesnapost vote, the Queen does have a very important role to play after the results have been announced.  The leader of the winning party will travel to Buckingham Palace where they will have a meeting with the Monarch during which she will ask them to form a Government on her behalf. Boris Johnson plans to hold a stripped-back Queenaposs Speech just days before Christmashe wins.Similar to the one we saw after the snap  election, it will be a much quicker affair without the usual pomp and ceremony.

title: young people pushed climate top
story: NewsopinionYoung people have pushed the climate to the top of the agenda in this electionNyasha Duri is a -year-old environmental and humanitarian campaigner working on sustainability, as well as serving as an ambassador for the #iwill campaignShareCommentsByNyasha Duri:,  DEC NewsopinionGreta Thunberg made headlines this week for saying that the global school strikes she has inspired “have achieved nothing”"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEvery single school in London breaches the World Health Organisation’s recommended annual pollution limits. I still remember the asthma attacks I suffered during my school days, which stopped me from pursuing athletics. In , nine year old Ella Kissi-Debrah died from a fatal asthma attack in Lewisham, following exposure to unlawful levels of pollution near her home. Young people cannot afford more excuses from parties on why they are not prioritising the environment. Our health is suffering, and across the world our peers are already dying from the climate crisis - with indigenous communities affected the most, as advocates such as Canada’s Autumn Peltier remind us. In the last year, we have seen children rise up in their hundreds of thousands to demand international climate action. In my work on sustainability, I have seen a real increase in the understanding that young people must be central to the conversation. Despite this, Greta Thunberg made headlines this week for saying that the global school strikes she has inspired “have achieved nothing”, as levels of CO continue to rise. I, however, think we can credit the determination showed by striking students for the increased focus on the climate crisis in this election. Nonetheless, Boris Johnson clearly felt the climate was not a sufficient priority - not even turning up to Channel ’s first-ever general election climate debate. Despite such discouraging signs, I feel that the climate crisis is of such grave importance that we can’t afford to limit ourselves with partisan politics. Whichever party makes it into power, I hope that they see it as an imperative to boost their engagement with young people’s voices on the environment. This was begun this year with Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairshearing recommendations on climate from the British Youth Council’s Youth Policy Advisory Group.

title: boy critical condition after nativity
story: NewsBoy in critical condition after his nativity costume is set alight by candleLondon Fire Brigade have warned parents and teachers from using candles after a St Thomas Becket Catholic Primary School pupil was set alight at Our Lady of the Annunciation Church in CroydonShareCommentsByJess GlassMilo Boyd:,  DEC NewsThe terrying incident unfolded at Our Lady of the Annunciation Church in Croydon "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young boy is in critical condition after his nativity costume was sparked by a candle last night. London Fire Brigade have warned parents and teachers away from using real candles around children after the horric accident. The boy, believed to be aged between  and , was rushed to hospital via air ambulance after he was seriously burned. His condition is said to be critical but stable. Witnesses said his costume was completely engulfed in seconds after he fell forwards while holding a candle at Our Lady of the Annunciation Church in Croydon. Two adults, thought to be teachers, were also burned and taken to hospital via road. London Fire Brigade assistant commissioner for fire safety Dan Daly said: This horric accident is a stark reminder of the risk real candles can pose. They are a completely unnecessary hazard when it comes to children and school plays. Sadly this isnapost the first time we have seen clothing and costumes set alight by candles and people need to recognise the risk and prevent these incidents from happening again. People should not be using real candles - especially around children, costumes and decorations - when there are far safer alternatives available.  The fire chief advised parents to choose LED candles over flame ones and to be particularly careful around potentially flammable Christmas decorations and costumes.The childaposs father was seen crying and heard shouting my son, a local shopkeeper told The Sun .Noel Campbell, head teacher of St Thomas Becket Catholic Primary School where the boy is a pupil, said: Our whole school community is devastated by the incident that occurred at our carol service yesterday. Our thoughts and prayers are with the child and his family at this dficult time. Following this incident, our pupils, staff and families are being given support.  London Ambulance Service attended the scene on Wednesday afternoon and later called officers from the politan Police, who are not investigating the incident. The Health and Safety Executive was also informed. Croydon Council will now review the incident with the school, the Archdiocese of Southwark and London Fire Brigade. A council spokesman said: Our thoughts are with all those affected by this very sad incident and we are supporting staff, pupils and the wider school community.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who was flown to London for -hour le-saving cancer surgery is still waiting to be operated on  days later.Janet Carter-Bowers has a rare soft tissue cancer that has grown around her spine, ribs and organs, Belfast Live reports.The woman, whose condition can only be addressed by three specialist surgeons who have not been available so far, is begging her daughters for help to get her home evenit means she will die. Her daughter Lauren Bowers, , from East Belfast, said: “We’re devastated to be separated from Mum knowing that she’s lying in a London hospital with a cancer that’ll kill her. “To know that she actually does have a chance to surviveshe gets surgery is wonderful, but to know they somehow can’t get the surgery organised is devastating - every day she’s getting worse. “The days have turned to weeks and hope has turned to despair and now she just wants to come home and face the consequences - but we know they would be fatal for her. “We were frightened for her having to travel to London for the surgery in the first place, but she’d no choice because the surgery is so complicated she needs a specialist team who can come together at the Royal Brompton Hospital. “The surgery is to remove a tumour that is wound around her spine and organs and it will take between  and  hours. “So when we got the call to get her over to London we were terried but we jumped at the chance. “My sister and her partner assisted mum on the journey and we assumed she’d have pre-operative tests and then surgery. Everyone was primed for it, we were trying to be brave and then we got delay after delay.  “And  days on we’re still waiting and mum is getting worse. She was facing into her th birthday today with some hope but it’s fading fast. Why take her all the way to Londonthe plan to operate just fades away ” Lauren added: “She went undiagnosed for almost three years and was given a number of dferent diagnosis. “The pain she was going through was horrendous, told she had bowel polyps, then erticulitis but in the end it was a team at AE who finally put her through the right tests and discovered she has soft tissue cancer. “She was admitted to hospital on morphine and the tests took six weeks to come back. It was cancer and it needed treated fast but it was another five months before anyone could say what was actually needed.  “She had chemo but reacted very badly to it and couldn’t continue with the treatment. “So the tumour was left to grow and it needs to be removed by surgery to give her a chance. “We were told the risks. The surgery could leave mum paralysed or it could kill her. But not having the surgery will kill her. “So her only chance is to have the operation and hope it goes well. “If the tumour is able to be removed in full, mum has been told she should make a good recovery. “We put our fears to the back of our head and got our hopes up and we were promised in August she would be operated as soon as possible.  Now it’s mid-December and mum is still lying in the specialist hospital far away from home and we’re no further on. “That tumour has been given five months growing time while we are still being promised the world and being let down repeatedly. “As a family we’re devastated and disgusted and we have lost any hope in our system. “Mum’s in London for specialist care from a specialist team. She cannot go anywhere , she cannot risk coming home. “Her physical health is deteriorating, her emotional and mental health is under huge pressure. “She was told she’d be operated on and recovered well enough to be home for Christmas. “But now we’ve been told the three specialist surgeons have not been able to get a date in their diary when they’re all available at the same time.  “The NHS is under enormous pressure, the staff are too and my mum who was a health care worker is the person paying the price. “We have every faith in the work of the medical teams butthey cannot actually manage to move my mum off the hospital ward and into surgery, then what hope do we have  “I would like someone to tell me why my lovely mother, who has cared for people all her working le, is being treated like this. I’d like to hear how anyone can justy this.”

title: mumps cases treble year medics
story: NewsMumps cases treble affecting thousands as medics warn of dangerous misinformationA dip in the number of people getting the vaccine  years ago due claims it could be linked to autism has been blamed for the worrying spike in university students in are Edinburgh, Cambridge, Oxford and BristolShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsCases of months have tripled since this time last year "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA severe mumps outbreak is sweeping universities - with more than , cases reported since the summer. The figure is three times as high as the number known to have contracted the condition in the same period last year. It is thought a dip in the number of children getting MMR japs in the past  years is to blame. Health chiefs are urging people to get vaccinated, warning that dodging jabs can be fatal. Among the affected universities are Edinburgh, Cambridge, Oxford and Bristol. Back in the late s, disgraced doctor Andrew Wakefield suggested there was a link between the MMR vaccination and autism - making many reluctant to get it done.  Simon Stevens, of NHS England, told the Daily Mail : Mumps is infectious and causes serious health complications, and the stark rise in cases is another reminder that opting out of protective jabs like MMR is dangerous and can make preventable diseases fatal.Dangerous misinformation about vaccines and falling uptake are a public health time bomb. Dr Doug Brown, of the British Society for Immunology, added: To curb this continuing spread of mumps we need  per cent of people to be vaccinated – a target that the UK has not reached for some years – and we are now seeing the effects of this failure. This important study set out to investigate some of the claims spread by MMR jab sceptics and fearful parents. The researchers behind the Danish study had also worked to disprove a now-disbarred gastroenterologistaposs Andrew Wakefieldaposs claims about the links between the vaccine and autism back in . Their latest paper is in the Annals of Internal Medicine , which is published by the American College of Physicians.They studied , children born in Denmark from  through to December , which is the biggest number studied to date. The researchers then followed up when the children turned one, and again in August . They looked into whether there were any links between the vaccine and autism to address criticism raised by the anti-vaccine lobby.Some vaccine doubters have claimed some groups of children are more susceptible to vaccine-caused autism.The researchers found this theory is . There were , children in the Danish study diagnosed with autism.But the researchers found no link between being vaccinated and the disorder - even in children who had autism risk factors like having a brother or sister who has been diagnosed with the disorder. Mumps is a contagious viral infection that can be spotted by painful swellings under the ears. It can lead to serious infections such as glandular fever and tonsillitis, and in extreme cases can turn to meningitisit moves to the outer layer of the brain.

story: NewsMum who weighed  stone turns le around after seven-year-old sons pleaLaura Cain, , feared she could be dead by Christmas, but was inspired to turn her le around by her seven-year-old son, who wanted to "enjoy a longer le together"ShareCommentsByAndrew Brown:,  DEC NewsLaura Cain, from Southport, weighed more than  stone when she decided to turn her le around "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who weighed  stone looks unrecognisable after an incredible transformation - having feared she could be dead before Christmasshe didnapost make a change. Laura Cain, , gorged on takeaways and scoffed her way through bread, barm cakes, butter, and chocolate, alongside cups of tea every day. But her seven-year-old son inspired her to lose weight so they could enjoy a longer le together. Laura, who at her heaviest weighed  stone, told the Liverpool Echo: “I thought I would be dead by now. Never did I think any of this would happen for me. “I have always been overweight. I was one of these people who join Slimming World, do it a while then give up. I also tried Weight Watchers, and those awful shake diets. “Over the last  years, I have struggled a lot with my health. In her s Laura, from Southport, developed swine flu and was placed on a le support machine in a desperate bid to survive. She was so ill afterwards, she had to learn how to walk again and tragically three years later, in , Laura contracted meningitis after giving birth to her son, Domanic. While fighting back from those traumatic episodes, brave Laura also had to contend with living with brittle asthma and fibromyalgia, and has also developed a huge hernia. Four years ago, Laura was referred by her asthma consultant to have weight loss surgery.  But a doctor told her the operation would not be possible until she lost enough weight. The mum said she tried ious ways of losing weight, but was making little headway until  when she began noticing inspiring posts appearing on Facebook by local Slimming World consultant Dee Wright. Laura said: “Dee and I messaged each other a few times but the thought of going to a new Slimming World group scared me. I kept thinking I was going to get judged. “But I knew one girl who was already a member at Deeaposs group.  She told me what a lovely group it was and how amazing Dee is, so that was it - I braved it. I got a taxi right to the front door and walked in to Dee welcoming me and give me a huge hug. “I stayed there for about seven or eight months but it just wasnapost the right time. My weight wasnapost shting, my head wasnapost in it. I tried a shake diet afterwards and that wasnapost working either so I gave up. However in December  Laura got a postcard through her door from Dee, saying encouraging her to . Laura walked back through the doors on January  to another big hug from Dee, but then got a huge shock. She said: I stood on the scales and was shocked to see I had hit  stone. It was horrible.”  Laura was given a target of losing two stone before her weight loss surgery, which she managed to do before going into hospital for her operation on April .  And that was the start of her fight to get her le back. Laura said: “I was so scared and nervous. I had never had surgery before.  “All I kept thinking was that I was doing this for my health and to be here to see my son grow up. “If it wasnapost for Dom, I wouldnapost be here.  “So I had surgery. I had a gastric sleeve which basically meant they removed two thirds of my stomach. It has made my stomach smaller so I canapost eat as much.  Laura, who went to school at Stanley High School in Southport, swapped her unhealthy ways and transformed her lestyle. Instead of fatty foods Laura now enjoys grape nuts or Weetabix for breakfast, tuna with salad or jacket potato for lunch Slimming World meals for tea. And now the mum has lost a third of her body weight - trimming down to an impressive  stone and seven pounds.  The mum added: “I could still eat badlyI wanted too, but I donapost. I stick to food optimising with Slimming World. I attend group every Wednesday for the love and support and amazing tips I get there. “If it wasnapost for Dee and her group I could not have done this. They supported me % and that is what I need and love. “I know I have haters out there who say I am cheating because I have had weight loss surgery but in fact no - it is just a tool to help me. “I have just been awarded my  stone award and I am now in the  stone bracket! I canapost remember the last time I was in the teens bracket.  “I still have a very long way to go. I have had a scan ahead of a possible hernia operation and now it is just another waiting game.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA school has apologised after its deputy head told pupils there is no Father Christmas. The comments were made during an assembly at Archbishop Sentamu School, in Hull - where pupils were asked to focus on Jesus this festive season instead of Santa The teacher is reported to have told pupils: “Christmas isn’t a time for presents, parties or dinners. It is a time for remembering the baby Jesus and the miracle of his birth, because as we all know there is no Father Christmas.”A shocked aunt, known as Amy, has spoken out after her nephew told her what had happened, reports Hull Live. “He is only , and we were in the queue with his younger brother to meet Santa at a grotto, and he whispered to me that Father Christmas wasn’t real”, she said. “I asked him what he meant and who told him that, and he said a teacher had told all of the kids in assembly. “I didn’t want to say anything too much at that time, because there were lots of children around, but he finally told me the whole story later on.” According to Amy, her nephew, who is in Year , had remained “tight-lipped and upset” by the teacher’s comments, and he only spoke about what he heard days after the assembly. “He told me the teacher kept going on about Jesus, instead of Father Christmas, so I told him Christmas can be about whatever you want it to be,” she said. “I told him Father Christmas is magic and so is Jesus, and there’s no reason you shouldn’t be able to believe in both. “He only left primary school in July, and it’s only right he stops believing when he wants to. “The school have no right to ruin the magic of Christmas for anyone.”

story: NewsTeenager finds new hope and a new friend at idyllic care homeRory is one of the teenagers who has found a new home in Tan-y-Bryn, North Wales at a care facility run by Action for Children where he can go fishing and look after his pet chickenShareCommentsByPoppy Danby:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsRory feeds a chicken alongside his support worker"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRunning through the fields with his pet chickens pecking at his feet, -year-old Rory is starting to settle into le in a children’s care home. He has been living here since it opened in July and shares it with just one other boy and their care workers – though more kids are soon to join them. In its idyllic rural setting, with apple trees and a lake for fishing, the home is far from the residential care institutions people imagine. This is particularly important for Rory, who has never lived in a children’s care home before. It certainly helped to be able to bring his four chickens with him to the home in Tan-y-Bryn, North Wales. He says: “I’ve had a lot of help to get settled in. It’s been extremely important to have the chickens with me. I hatched them and they wouldn’t be able to survive with someone . “I feed them, water them, empty their pen, put down new hay and collect their eggs. They’ve settled in really well.” His home is run by Action For Children, for which generous readers have already raised £, in our Give Kids a Cracking Christmas appeal. The home focuses on green therapy and getting kids outdoors. Rory says: “It’s really good because I like playing with my chickens, walking, cycling and fishing.” Such initiatives have changed the le of Ieuan Read, , who has been in a nearby Action For Children home for eight years. Staff at Tan-y-Bryn used to work at the other residence and Ieuan still visits them. Registered manager Caroline Morris says: “We want to make it as normal as possible for young people having Christmas in care. “Christmas Eve is when they tend to get really excited, so we take them out to get rid of all their energy and anxieties. story: NewsVet mistakenly euthanises dog after calling wrong owner during surgeryAndrea Martinez said her family brought Ziggy to an animal hospital after the dog experienced breathing and eating problemsShareCommentsByChiara Fiorillo:,  DEC NewsAndrea Martinezs dachshund puppy, Ziggy, was euthanised "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has claimed a vet euthanised her dog after calling another owner seeking consent to put the pet down. Andrea Martinez said her family brought their dachsund puppy, Ziggy, to an animal hospital in Utah, US, after the dog experienced breathing and eating problems. A veterinarian recommended Ziggy undergo surgery and Andreaaposs family agreed to leave him at hospital overnight for the procedure. During the surgery, it became clear the puppy would need a more complicated and expensive operation. The family says the vet mistakenly called the owner of a dferent dog, also named Ziggy, and explained the situation, asking whether she would like to proceed with the surgery or put the pooch down. The other owner opted to have the pet euthanised, not knowing the dog in question was not hers. At .am on Monday, Andrea received a call telling her Ziggy had died. “He was our baby, it was my daughter’s best friend, my dog’s best friend, it was ours. Money wasn’t an issue, she said. How do you tell a -year-old her best friend died and we didnapost have a choice to try everything to stop him from dying.  This whole thing seriously makes me so sick to my stomach, she added. After being put on hold, the woman found out the vet had called the wrong person. Then he got back on there and he apologized and said, ‘I’m so sorry that this happened, we got confused and ended up calling another dog’s mom, she added. Andrea said the vet has been very apologetic, waiving their bill and giving them a nice urn, a plaque and a Christmas ornament with Ziggyaposs paw print. She said Ziggy used to follow her everywhere, cuddled with her every night and also helped her cope with anxiety, The Sun reports. On Tuesday, Martinez posted a message on her Facebook page saying she has decided not to pursue legal action against the animal hospital.She said: It was a honest mistake, they owned it, and are taking steps to make things okay.

title: flight mh370 mystery never solved
story: NewsFlight MH mystery may never be solved because of crucial lost  minutesThe Malaysian Airlines jet, which was carrying  passengers from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, disappeared from radar just seconds after entered into Vietnamese airspaceShareCommentsByDavid Coleman:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe doomed Malaysia Airlines plane took off from Kuala Lumpur International Airport "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mystery of doomed Malaysia Airlines flight MH may never be solved as it lost contact with air traffic controllers during a crucial  minute window, according to reports. The jet, which was carrying  passengers from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, disappeared from radar just seconds after entered into Vietnamese airspace. Crucially, this was missed by ground crew in Malaysia who had a busy schedule at the time the jet vanished. When the team in Kuala Lumpur finally noticed the Boeing aposs disappearance, they presumed it had been taken over by air traffic controllers in Ho Chi Minh, the Atlantic reports. The Vietnamese team had noticed the jet on their monitors and then saw it vanish - but crucially - it is believed they failed to report the issue to their Malaysian counterparts. A full  minutes passed before ground crew in Kuala Lumpur became aware one of their jets had vanished. The Malaysian Aviation Safety Networkis certain that the aircraft was captured mid-flight. Evidence is mounting that the crash, which has become of the greatest aviation mysteries of all time, was a murder-suicide. New flight data suggests some abnormal turns [were] made by the  [that] can only be done manually. French investigators claim captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah was a troubled, lonely man who deliberately killed all passengers and crew on board the flight. But it will take around a year to go through all of the information received from Boeing, sources said in July. A source, who is aposclose to the investigationapos said: Some abnormal turns made by the  can only be done manually. So someone was at the helm.  It is too early to state categorically. But nothing is credited that anyone  could have entered the cockpit. The informant told Le Parisien the new development amid Franceaposs judicial inquiry into the crash. It is the only country to conduct one as of yet. Data analysis indicates the Boeing -ER flew over the Indian Ocean until it ran out of fuel and violently slammed into the water with  people on board. It is suspected the planeaposs passenger cabin was deliberately depressurised by Shah to kill everyone on board hours before the crash.  Before doing so, he could have put on an oxygen mask in the cockpit so he could continue to fly the aircraft for hours. At around the same time the cabin was depressurised the electrical system was deliberately turned off, making the plane impossible to track by satellite. An FBI inspection of Shahaposs Microsoft flight simulator at home showed he had tested a flight roughly matching the path of MH, ending in the Indian Ocean after running out of fuel. His voice was heard in the final radio communication less than two minutes before the plane began to ert from its flight path from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March , . One of his lelong friends told the Atlantic that he had reluctantly come to the conclusion that Shah deliberately crashed the plane, given the evidence amassed by independent investigators.  The friend, who wasnapost named, said: “It’s hard to reconcile with the man I knew. But it’s the necessary conclusion.” The friend said Shah likely tricked his inexperienced -year-old co-pilot, Fariq Hamid, who was on his final training flight, into leaving the cockpit and locked him out. He said: “Zaharie was an examiner. All he had to say was ‘Go check something in the cabinapos, and the guy would have been gone.”

title: dark blues squad a bit short says mcpake ahead of transfer window
story: Manager James McPake is finalising plans for some winter additions to improve his struggling Dundee side as the January transfer window nears.In the summer, the Dens gaffer brought in a dozen new faces as the club aimed to recover quickly from Premiership relegation.He accepts that’s taken longer than everyone at the club had hoped but has vowed that will be the last window with wholesale changes to the Dark Blues playing squad.James said: “We’re speaking about how we’re going to recruit and what is needed in this window and the next to make us better.“We have been looking ahead at the January window since the summer. story: Dundee United youngster Louis Appere admits he was relieved to get on the scoresheet against Alloa on Saturday – and insists he is now targeting more.Hitman Appere has enjoyed a breakthrough season for the Terrors, so far, notching three goals and grabbing a host of assists in  games – mostly playing wide.However, he admits he is keen to follow up his winner in the - success against Alloa with more goals after enduring an -game drought since his last in the - derby win back in August.“It’s been bothering me a little bit,” the -year-old said.“Obviously, I’ve been happy with how I’ve been playing but I want to score goals.“I can set up goals but I need to prove I can score them as well. title: we deserved more says dark blues boss mcpake
story: Dundee boss James McPake says his side “deserved more” from their trip to Arbroath after their run without a win extended to four matches.The Dark Blues fell further behind the top teams in the Championship as they had to come from behind to earn a point at a windswept Gayfield.The first half saw the home side create a number of chances before Bobby Linn curled in a beauty on  minutes.Dundee got themselves level through Kane Hemmings’ fine header on  minutes and could have gone on to win it with opportunities late in the game.James was pleased to see his side show “heart” in the second period but accepts they need to show more to get back to winning ways.He said: “We challenged them at half-time that we needed to see more – and a bit of character.“We came into this one on the back of three defeats and to go in - down at half-time after being questioned, they showed that character.“Is it enough  No, because we didn’t win the game.“We challenged the players and they were better second half.“On the basis of the second-half chances I think we deserved more. vw, px"  “We had a couple of clear-cut ones but they were the better team in the first half, no doubt about that.“It was much of a muchness first half but they posed more threat to our goal. story: West Aberdeenshire and Kincardine is another volatile seat in which discussions over Brexit and Scottish independence continue to dominate.Despite a long Liberal Democrat tradition in the seat in the past, this is an election battle expected to be a two-horse race between the Conservatives and the SNP.Theresa May’s former parliamentary aide Andrew Bowie is hoping to win the seat again for the Tories, claiming to be “confident but not complacent” of success.Mr Bowie, who turned over a , SNP majority in  to win the seat with % of the vote, said Brexit and Scottish independence are the two main topics on the doors, but added voters in the north-east also feel “short-changed” by the SNP government in Scotland.He added: “There’s only been one choice, either the SNP or myself as the Conservative.“Brexit and independence are the two most dominant issues.“I think there’s a real desire for politicians to stop talking about those issues and get on with the day job and issues like the health service, broadband coverage and education.”The Conservative candidate claims voters in the constituency have had enough of the north-east being used as a “cash cow”.He added: “One of the constant refrains from voters is they want the north-east to get their fair share.“There’s a recognition that we’re the only party standing up for the north-east of Scotland.”However, he is facing off of Brexit, something they didn’t vote for largely in Aberdeenshire.“They’ve completely changed their minds in a lot of cases on the issue of Scottish independence.“They maybe voted No in  for they actually realise what a great deal they’re getting compared to the south of the border.”Mr Mutch added that while the Tories’  campaign strategy, which put opposition to a second independence referendum front and centre, may have worked to “some degree”, he doesn’t think it will work this time round.He said: “My feeling is that may have worked for them in  to some degree because people story: A Robert Gordon University graduate who looked after both her parents following a le-saving operation was glad to finally graduate after four of the hardest years of her le.Hannah Lawson, , of Stonehaven, was in the fourth and final year of her accounting and finance course when her father Colin underwent a kidney transplant which came under unusual circumstances.He was involved in an organ swap where his we Lesley offered one of her kidneys to another patient, with Colin receiving a matching one from someone .With both her parents bed-bound and recovering, Hannah combined her exam studies with looking after them for eight weeks.Yesterday, she graduated with a : BA honours degree and celebrated with her family.She said: “It feels good to say that I have made it to graduation after a hard four years for all of us.“It was dficult both at home and trying to find the time to study at university, but I feel great that I’m graduating.“Looking after them never bothered me at the time and I just got on with it.”Colin suffered a heart attack four years ago and had been on kidney dialysis until his le-saving operation on November  last year.He continues to have ongoing health problems but no longer needs round-the-clock care.Lesley hailed her daughter for being a le-saver during the couple’s vital recovery.She said: “We are incredibly proud of her and can’t believe she’s done it after everything she’s had to endure.“We could not have done this without Hannah’s invaluable help and are amazed that she got up every morning to look after us and go to university as well.”Colin added: “We got a chance of a kidney but it was no use, so my we stepped in and we did a three-way swap and Hannah looked after us all.“I think she would have got a firstit wasn’t for me.”Hannah is looking for a graduate job in accountancy.
